prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 Continuum: GB 1713+2148 and SDSS J1659+2101
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The project is designed to measure the far-infrared continuum luminosity at Band 7 for GB 1713+2148 and SDSS J1659+2101.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We estimate the expected flux density at 350 GHz for our targets using their flux densities at 1.4 GHz with the assumption of spectral index as -1, which is a fairly conservative approach given the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of the general RLQ population. Furthermore, we also expect higher far-infrared luminosity for our targets than typical RLQs. The expected 350 GHz flux density ranges from 0.1 to 1.8 mJy. Thus we require a continuum sensitivity of 0.05 mJy, which gives the SNR ~ 2--36 (with the median value of 6) which should be considered as a lower limit of SNR for each source. With the proposed configurations (34 12-m antenna array, dual polarization, 0.3" angular resolution, typical sky, etc.), the needed exposure time for each target is ~1000 s. With the added calibration and overheads, the total time required for all proposed observations is 12.2 hours.
None of our targets reside at Declination > +40 degree, in which case the antenna shadowing is problematic. Although for the 12-m array, the antenna shadowing becomes significant (>5%) at Declination = +25 degree for compact configuration, only one of our targets is slightly north (Declination = +25.7 degree) and our observation will apply extended configuration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA imaging of 13 highly radio-loud quasars at z > 4 to obtain their far-infrared luminosity and investigate its correlation with their X-ray luminosity. A positive correlation between these two quantities may indicate a dominating jet-linked X-ray emission mechanism of inverse Compton scattering the host-galaxy photon fields produced by starbursts. This mechanism represents a significant feedback process by active galactic nuclei to their host-galaxy evolution. With this mechanism, the enhanced star-forming activity at high redshifts can also explain the X-ray emission enhancement of z > 4 highly radio-loud quasars over their counterparts at lower redshifts.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Macalester College
Dept of Astronomy & Astrophysics, Pennsylvania State University
